facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 83 of 1953 filed in Supreme Court under article 132(1) of the Constitution of India.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 83 of 1953. Appeal under article 132 1  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment

facts.text: Appeal from Judgment and Order dated 25th August 1953 of High Court of Judicature at Patna in Criminal Appeal No. 410 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal under article 132 1  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order dated the 25th August 1953 of the High Court of Judicature at Patna in Criminal Appeal No. 410 of 1951.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on December 2, 1954 by DAS J.

anchor.surface_text: 1954. December 2. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS J.-This is an appeal from a judgment of the High Court of Judicature at Patna

facts.text: Appeal arises out of criminal trial held in district of Hazaribagh in State of Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal arises out of a criminal trial held in the district of Hazaribagh in the State of Bihar. The case against the appellants was investigated by the local police

facts.text: Case against appellants investigated by local police.

anchor.surface_text: The case against the appellants was investigated by the local police and on the 4th June, 1951 a challan was submitted before the Sub-Divisional Magistrate.

facts.text: Challan submitted before Sub-Divisional Magistrate on 4th June 1951.

anchor.surface_text: and on the 4th June, 1951 a challan was submitted before the Sub-Divisional Magistrate. The Sub-Divisional Magistrate passed the following order in the order-sbeet-

facts.text: Sub-Divisional Magistrate ordered record sent to Deputy Commissioner Hazaribagh for transferring to file of Special Magistrate for trial.

anchor.surface_text: The Sub-Divisional Magistrate passed the following order in the order-sbeet- Let the record be sent to the Dy. Commr., Hazaribagh for. transferring it to the file of the Spl. Magistrate for trial.

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner ordered case withdrawn and transferred to Mr. S. F. Azam, Magistrate with powers u/s 30 CrPC for disposal.

anchor.surface_text: On the record being placed before the Deputy Commissioner, the latter passed following order- Perused S.D.0s order-sheet. Withdrawn and transferred to the file of Mr. S. F. Azam, Magte. with powers u s 30, Cr. C. for favour of disposal.

facts.text: Appellants tried by Mr. S. F. Azam, Magistrate of first class exercising powers under section 30 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants were then tried by Mr. S. F. Azam, Magistrate of the first class exercising powers under section 30 of the Code of Criminal Procedure on charges

facts.text: Appellants charged under sections 366 and 143 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: exercising powers under section 30 of the Code of Criminal Procedure on charges under sections 366 and 143 of the Indian Penal Code

facts.text: Each appellant convicted under sections 366 and 143 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: on charges under sections 366 and 143 of the Indian Penal Code and each of them was companyvicted under both the sections and sentenced to rigorous imprison- ment for five years under section 366, Indian Penal Code,

facts.text: Each appellant sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for five years under section 366 IPC, separate sentence under section 143.

anchor.surface_text: each of them was companyvicted under both the sections and sentenced to rigorous imprison- ment for five years under section 366, Indian Penal Code, numberseparate sentence having been passed under section 143.

facts.text: Appellants preferred appeal to High Court of Judicature at Patna.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants preferred an appeal to the High Court of Judicature at Patna. The appeal was heard by a Bench companysisting of S. K. Das and C. P. Sinha, JJ.

facts.text: High Court appeal heard by Bench of S.K. Das and C.P. Sinha JJ.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal was heard by a Bench companysisting of S. K. Das and C. P. Sinha, JJ. There was a difference of opinion between the two learned Judges as to the companystitutionality

facts.text: Difference of opinion between S.K. Das J. and C.P. Sinha J. on constitutionality of section 30 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: There was a difference of opinion between the two learned Judges as to the companystitutionality of section 30 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. S. K. Das, J., took the view that the impugned section did number bring about any discrimination

facts.text: S.K. Das J. held section 30 CrPC does not offend article 14.

anchor.surface_text: S. K. Das, J., took the view that the impugned section did number bring about any discrimination or inequality between persons similarly circumstanced and companysequently did number offend the equal protection clause of the Constitution,

facts.text: C.P. Sinha J. held section 30 CrPC hit by article 14.

anchor.surface_text: while C. P. Sinha, J., was of the opinion that 1048 the section was hit by article 14. The appeal was thereupon placed before Reuben, C. J.,

facts.text: Appeal placed before Reuben C.J. who agreed with S.K. Das J. that section 30 does not violate article 14.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal was thereupon placed before Reuben, C. J., who in agreement with S. K. Das, J., held that section 30 did number violate the inhibition of article 14.

facts.text: High Court upheld conviction but reduced sentence.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Chief Justice upheld the companyviction but reduced the sentence. On application by the appellants the High Court granted them a certificate

facts.text: High Court granted certificate under article 132(1) to appellants on application.

anchor.surface_text: On application by the appellants the High Court granted them a certificate under article 132 1  and the present appeal has been filed accordingly.

facts.text: Appellants contend trial by section 30 Magistrate instead of Court of Session infringes article 14.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Advocate appearing in support of the appeal companytends before us, as was done before the High Court, that there had been an infraction of the fundamental rights guaranteed to the appellants under article 14 of the Constitution of India.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds no infringement of article 14.

anchor.surface_text: On the facts and circumstances of this case we find ourselves in agreement with S. K. Das, J., and Reuben, C. J., and hold that numbercase of infringement of fundamental right under Article 14 has been made out.

well-established that while article 14 forbids class legislation, it does not forbid reasonable classification for the purposes of legislation. In order, however, to pass the test of permissible classification two conditions must be fulfilled, namely, (i) that the classification must be founded on an intelligible differentia which distinguishes persons or things that are grouped together from others left out of the group and (ii) that differentia must have a rational relation to the object sought to be achieved by the statute in question.

issues.text: whether this apparent discrimination offends against the equal protection clause of our Constitution

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, to see whether this apparent discrimination offends against the equal protection clause of our Constitution. The provisions of article 14 of the Constitution have come up for discussion before this Court in a number of cases., namely, Chiranjit Lal Chowdhuri v. The Union of India 1 , The State of Bombay v. F. N. Balsara 2 , The State of West Bengal v. Anwar Ali Sarkar 3 , Kathi Raning Rawat v. The State of Sau-

issues.text: whether, though a law be fair on its face and impartial in operation, if it is administered by public authority with an evil eye and an unequal hand so as practically to make illegal discrimination between persons in similar circumstances

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the appellants, however, contends, on the strength of the decision of the Supreme Court of America in Yick, Wo v. Peter Hopkins 1  that though a law be fair on its face and impartial in operation, yet, if it is administered by public authority with an evil eye and an unequal hand so as practically to make illegal discrimination between persons in similar circumstances materially to their rights, the denial of equal justice is still within the prohibition of the Constitution.

issues.text: whether the classification [under section 30] must be founded on an intelligible differentia which distinguishes persons or things that are grouped together from others left out of the group and that differentia must have a rational relation to the object sought to be achieved by the statute in question

anchor.surface_text: well-established that while article 14 forbids class legislation, it does not forbid reasonable classification for the purposes of legislation. In order, however, to pass the test of permissible classification two conditions must be fulfilled, namely, (i) that the classification must be founded on an intelligible differentia which distinguishes persons or things that are grouped together from others left out of the group and (ii) that differentia must have a rational relation to the object sought to be achieved by the statute in question.

arguments.claim: Trial by section 30 Magistrate instead of Court of Session infringes article 14

anchor.surface_text: The learned Advocate appearing in support of the appeal contends before us, as was done before the High Court, that there had been an infraction of the fundamental rights guaranteed to the appellants under article 14 of the Constitution of India. The complaint is that the appellants had been tried by a section 30 Magistrate and not by a Court of Session.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: een at any stage any intentional or purposeful discrimination as against the appellants by the Sab-Divisional Magistrate or the District Magistrate or

arguments.court_reasoning: No discrimination; reasonable geographical classification with rational nexus

arguments.claim: Sessions trial more advantageous due to commitment proceedings, jury or assessors

anchor.surface_text: A section 30 Magistrate is enjoined by that section to try the case brought before him as a Magistrate and accordingly in cases like the present case he will follow the warrant procedure which is different from the procedure followed by a Court of Session. The substance of the grievance is that a trial before the Sessions Judge is much more advantageous to the accused person in that he gets the benefit of the commitment proceedings before a Magistrate and then a trial before the Sessions Judge with the aid of the jury or assessors.
while C. P. Sinha, J., was of the opinion that 1048 the section was hit by article 14.

Das, J., took the view that the impugned section did not bring about any discrimination or inequality between persons similarly circumstanced and consequently did not offend the equal protection clause of the Constitution,

arguments.claim: Article 14 permits reasonable classification if intelligible differentia with rational nexus

anchor.surface_text: It is now well-established that while article 14 forbids class legislation, it does not forbid reasonable classification for the purposes of legislation. In order, however, to pass the test of permissible classification two conditions must be fulfilled, namely, (i) that the classification must be founded on an intelligible differentia which distinguishes persons or things that are grouped together from others left out of the group and (ii) that differentia must have a rational relation to the object sought to be achieved by the statute in question.

arguments.claim: Section 30 based on geographical classification which is valid

anchor.surface_text: The classification may be founded on different bases namely, geographical, or according to objects or occupations or the like. What is necessary is that there must be a nexus between the basis of classification and the object of the Act under consideration... Section 30, however, empowers the State Government in certain areas to invest the District Magistrate or any Magistrate of the first class with power to try as a Magistrate all offences not punishable with death.

arguments.claim: Section 30 overrides sections 28 and 29; adds additional court, no discrimination

anchor.surface_text: Section 28... subject to the other provisions... Section 30... notwithstanding anything contained in section 28 or section 29... The effect of the State Government investing... is to bring into being an additional court...

arguments.claim: No discriminatory administration shown; judicial discretion controls

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the appellants, however, contends... Yick Wo... It is thus clear that the ultimate decision... depends ultimately on the proper exercise of judicial discretion by the Magistrate concerned.

arguments.claim: Section 30 does not abrogate section 28 entirely; adds court

anchor.surface_text: It is not, however, claimed by the learned Attorney-General that section 30 abrogates or overrides altogether the provisions of section 28...

holdings.text: hold that no case of infringement of fundamental right under Article 14 has been made out

anchor.surface_text: On the facts and circumstances of this case we find ourselves in agreement with S. K. Das, J., and Reuben, C. J., and hold that no case of infringement of fundamental right under Article 14 has been made out.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with High Court majority; applies reasonable classification test to Section 30 CrPC; geographical basis has intelligible differentia and rational nexus; no evidence of discriminatory administration

holdings.text: while article 14 forbids class legislation, it does not forbid reasonable classification for the purposes of legislation. In order, however, to pass the test of permissible classification two conditions must be fulfilled, namely, (i) that the classification must be founded on an intelligible differentia which distinguishes persons or things that are grouped together from others left out of the group and (ii) that differentia must have a rational relation to the object sought to be achieved by the statute in question

anchor.surface_text: It is now well-established that while article 14 forbids class legislation, it does not forbid reasonable classification for the purposes of legislation. In order, however, to pass the test of permissible classification two conditions must be fulfilled, namely, (i) that the classification must be founded on an intelligible differentia which distinguishes persons or things that are grouped together from others left out of the group and (ii) that differentia must have a rational relation to the object sought to be achieved by the statute in question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Restates and applies settled law from prior Supreme Court decisions on Article 14

holdings.text: The effect of the State Government investing the District Magistrate or any Magistrate of the first class with power under section 30 is to bring into being an additional court in which all offences not punishable with death become triable

anchor.surface_text: The effect of the State Government investing the District Magistrate or any Magistrate of the first class with power under section 30 is to bring into being an additional court in which all offences not punishable with death become triable. In other words, the effect of the exercise of authority by the State Government under section 30 is, as it were, to add in the 8th column of the second schedule the Magistrate so em- powered as a Court before whom all offences not punishable with death will also be triable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 30 operates notwithstanding sections 28 and 29; adds to courts listed in Schedule II without exclusion; textual reading shows no abrogation

holdings.text: the section itself does not bring about any discrimination whatever

anchor.surface_text: In this sense, the section itself does not bring about any discrimination whatever. The section only authorises the State Government to invest certain Magistrates with power to try all offences not punishable with death and this authority the State can exercise only in the specified places.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Classification on territorial basis; power conferred only in specified areas; risk falls equally on all offenders

holdings.text: all of which make this classification quite a reasonable one

anchor.surface_text: S. K. Das, J., and the learned Chief Justice have in their respective judgments referred to certain circumstances, e.g. the distance between the place of occurrence and the headquarters where the Court of Session functions at considerable intervals, the inconvenience of bringing up witnesses from the interior, the difficulty of finding in the backward or out of the way places sufficient number of suitable persons to act as jurors or assessors, all of which make this classification quite a reasonable one.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Geographical/territorial classification valid; rational nexus to local needs, distance to sessions court, witness/juror issues in remote areas

holdings.text: article 14 condemns discrimination not only by a substantive law but also by a law of procedure

anchor.surface_text: It is also well established by the decisions of this Court that article 14 condemns discrimination not only by a substantive law but also by a law of procedure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies to procedural laws like CrPC; settled by prior decisions

holdings.text: the ultimate decision as to whether a person charged under section 366 should be tried by the Court of Session or by a section 30 Magistrate does not depend merely on the whim or idiosyncrasies of the police or the executive Government but depends ultimately on the proper exercise of judicial discretion by the Magistrate concerned

anchor.surface_text: It is thus clear that the ultimate decision as to whether a person charged under section 366 should be tried by the Court of Session or by a section 30 Magistrate does not depend merely on the whim or idiosyncrasies of the police or the executive Government but depends ultimately on the proper exercise of judicial discretion by the Magistrate concerned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Judicial options under ss 347, 528, 208-213 CrPC intervene; no evidence of unequal administration or evil intent

holdings.text: there is no suggestion whatever that there has been at any stage any intentional or purposeful discrimination as against the appellants

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned at once that in the present case there is no suggestion whatever that there has been at any stage any intentional or purposeful discrimination as against the appellants by the Sub-Divisional Magistrate or the District Magistrate or the section 30 Magistrate who actually tried the accused.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No facts shown of discriminatory enforcement; distinguishes Yick Wo; judicial review available

anchor.surface_text: It is now well-established that while article 14 forbids class legislation, it does not forbid reasonable classification for the purposes of legislation. In order, however, to pass the test of permissible classification two conditions must be fulfilled, namely, (i) that the classification must be founded on an intelligible differentia which distinguishes persons or things that are grouped together from others left out of the group and (ii) that differentia must have a rational relation to the object sought to be achieved by the statute in question.
On the facts and circumstances of this case we find ourselves in agreement with S. K. Das, J., and Reuben, C. J., and hold that no case of infringement of fundamental right under Article 14 has b

anchor.surface_text: The effect of the State Government investing the District Magistrate or any Magistrate of the first class with power under section 30 is to bring into being an additional court in which all offences not punishable with death become triable. In other words, the effect of the exercise of authority by the State Government under section 30 is, as it were, to add in the 8th column of the second schedule the Magistrate so em- powered as a Court before whom all offences not punishable with death will also be triable.
On the facts and circumstances of this case we find ourselves in agreement with S. K. Das, J., and Reuben, C. J., and hold that no case of infringement of fundamental right under Article 14 has b

anchor.surface_text: It is thus clear that the ultimate decision as to whether a person charged under section 366 should be tried by the Court of Session or by a section 30 Magistrate does not depend merely on the whim or idiosyncrasies of the police or the executive Government but depends ultimately on the proper exercise of judicial discretion by the Magistrate concerned.
